I hope this will fix the issue #188 , i didn't have a test case : /

data.title: Material does not serialize the "name" property
data.body: The `Material` class should serialize the name property into the `Savable`.

data.title: Suggestion: Support distance field based text rendering
data.body:
Valve published a paper in 2007 describing a distance field based approach for rendering texts.
See http://www.valvesoftware.com/publications/2007/SIGGRAPH2007_AlphaTestedMagnification.pdf

Texts rendered in a 3D environment with this technique looks a lot nicer from near and far than bitmap fonts. Adding support for this kind of font rendering to jME would be great.

Here is a blog post that includes source code and has further links in the comment section:
http://bitsquid.blogspot.de/2010/04/distance-field-based-rendering-of.html

data.title: Centered BitmapText is rendered blurry
Updating the frustum does not work as expected
data.body:
There seems to be a problem when updating the frustum, camera and/or viewport.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Resize a viewport so it has another aspect ratio as before
2. Update camera aspect ratio
3. Notice that the resulting rendering is stretched

Please see this discussion for details, including code sample:
http://hub.jmonkeyengine.org/t/aspect-ratio-not-updated-when-resizing-viewport/33936/

data.title: Font creator doesn't create more than 256 characters
data.body:
Font creator doesn't create more than 256 characters. The Font Creator lets the user select the char range and even shows them on the preview, but the end result contains just one page with 256 characters max.
![fontcreator](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8344766/10146705/f10ad55e-6632-11e5-8dc3-bdf29b212483.png)

Easy fix would be just to produce one page with the given character range (max displayable char...). If I understood correctly, JME does read these, no matter what the max range is. Also the preview image could be inside a scrollable container. As it tends to eat up and hide all the controls when it is big enough.

Here some discussion from the forums (also pin pointed some of the code points which might be related):
http://hub.jmonkeyengine.org/t/font-creator-for-jmp/16273/30

data.title: Centered text is rendered blurry by class 'BitmapText'
data.body:
When using BitmapText to render a string while its alignment is set to "Center" some of the lines appear blurry, while others don't.

What it should look like:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/fj1xldsco0pd5yj/centered-text-nice.png

What it actually looks like:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/j3d8l43y99wdvif/centered-text-ugly.png

The reason for this is that class 'Letters', which does the actual alignment calculation, for centered lines calculates a gapX position that is not always an integer number, i.e. that is not pixel-perfect, resulting in the blurry text. IMHO the x coordinates of the rendered text should always be set to a whole number.

This could simply be achieved by casting the result of the calculation in line 217 of class 'com.jme3.font.Letters' to (int).

data.title: AndroidLocator fix for paths starting with /
native bullet does not work on Android 5 (?)

milestone.description:
jMonkeyEngine SDK 3.1

Highlights:
- Gradle
- Native Bullet physics
- NetBeans 8.x
- iOS support

data.body:
Due to the new Java runtime (ART) in Android 5, there are stricter checks on JNI calls. It seems to cause native crashes on native bullet.
Need to test native bullet on Android 5 to see how well it works.

data.title: Asset paths that begin with "/" don't work on Android

milestone.description:
jMonkeyEngine SDK 3.1

Highlights:
- Gradle
- Native Bullet physics
- NetBeans 8.x
- iOS support

data.body: Due to the changes in jME 3.1 to use Android's `AssetManager` instead of the `ClasspathLocator`, paths that begin with a forward slash no longer work.

data.title: Reduce uniform changes by comparing them before frame
data.body:
See:
https://github.com/jMonkeyEngine/jmonkeyengine/pull/292

Reuse smaller objects where the comparison cost is low, especially the matrices, wich stay stable for a whole frame.

data.title: Delete close() of ByteArrayOutputStream type objecs
data.body: According to the Oracle's [docummentation](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/ByteArrayOutputStream.html#close%28%29): "Closing a `ByteArrayOutputStream` has no effect. The methods in this class can be called after the stream has been closed without generating an `IOException`."

data.title: Optimise Strings concatenation
data.body:
In the `toString()` method concatenation will be performed during the runtime, because not all parameters are `String` type literals.
That is why it is better to use `StringBuilder` here.

data.title: FastMath nearestPowerOfTwo() speedup
Bug in Ray.intersectWherePlanarQuad(V3f, V3f, V3f, V3f)
data.body:
There seems to be a bug in method `Ray.intersectWherePlanarQuad(Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f)`, or more precisely in method `Ray.intersects(Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f, boolean, boolean)` when called with `true` as value for the second boolean parameter ('quad').

It seems as if the x-bound is not correctly calculated. When casting a ray the y-values are in the expected range. The x-values however seem to reach positive infinity and intersect with everything right of the quad origin.

Example:
I'm calling the method like so:
`ray.intersectWherePlanarQuad(new Vector3f(0, 0, 0), new Vector3f(1, 0, 0), new Vector3f(0, 1, 0), res);`
This is basically a quad of size (1|1) with its origin at (0|0). Right? I cast a ray from the current mouse position, using code from the JMonkey forum. The ray is constructed correctly, as it works for other picking tasks.

When casting the ray, the resulting y-values range from 0 to 1 as expected. Also only hits are returned when the mouse is inside the expected y-bounds (from 0 to 1 in world coordinates in my example scene).
The resulting x-values, however, start at 0 at (0|*) and seemingly go on forever in positive x-direction, without stopping at (1|*) when reaching the right border of the quad. It seems as if there are no bounds in x-direction.

When calling `Ray.intersects(Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f, boolean, boolean)` and passing in `false` for parameter `quad` it works again. But then only the lower-left triangle is checked for intersections, of course.

data.title: Eliminates the duplicated code
data.body: Shortening code using Java7's catch block, that can handle exceptions of the different types.

data.title: Fixed wrong BoundingBox transformation, when using negative scaling values
data.body:
I'm using jMonkeyEngine to display content, that was created for DirectX, and therefore I have to use a negative scaled z axis.

The bounding box of a rotated and negative scaled object, is totally messed up.
![wrongboundingbox](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9250103/9991830/bdbb0914-606d-11e5-9588-48f07af7ca42.PNG)

Using the absolute value of scale, when calculating the scaled bounding box extent, eliminates the problem.
![fixedboundingbox](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9250103/9991833/c3e33b5e-606d-11e5-8e97-8582e287cf2a.PNG)

data.title: use normal for irradiance, not reflvec
Check values of math constants to ensure they were not accidently changed
data.body: Constants like `Vector3f.ZERO` and others in the math package should be checked each frame (via assertion, or debug option) to ensure they remain what they are supposed to be. This prevents accidental changes by user code.

data.title: Make AudioNode constructors less confusing
data.body:
Currently we have constructors taking a name, name + boolean, or name + two booleans. There's no need for this complexity. Its best to just have a single constructor specifying the asset manager, the name of the audio file, and whether its buffered or streamed. The documentation should clearly specify what are the differences between buffered or streamed sources and when to use either.

E.g.

``` java
audioNode = new AudioNode(assetManager, "Music/Song123.ogg", Type.Streaming)
```

or

``` java
audioNode = new AudioNode(assetManager, "Sound/Misc/Hit.ogg", Type.Buffered)
```

Also the streamCache option should always be true, since it is unknown whether the user wants the sound to be looping, its best not to guess and assume it should support looping always.

data.title: IllegalStateException when playing sound (JME 3.1 Alpha 1)
data.body:
The following code works fine in 3.0 stable, but not in 3.1 Alpha 1

``` java
audioStep.playInstance();   // same for .play() method
```

Where audioStep is an AudioNode loaded up with a mono ogg file. Used for player's footsteps. Other sound files throw the below exception too, so it doesn't seem to be the audio file itself.

``` java
Exception in thread "jME3 Audio Decoder" java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot use setTime on a stream that is not seekable. You must load the file with the streamCache option set to true
    at com.jme3.audio.AudioStream.setTime(AudioStream.java:217)
    at com.jme3.audio.openal.ALAudioRenderer.fillStreamingSource(ALAudioRenderer.java:724)
    at com.jme3.audio.openal.ALAudioRenderer.updateInDecoderThread(ALAudioRenderer.java:949)
    at com.jme3.audio.openal.ALAudioRenderer.run(ALAudioRenderer.java:245)
at com.jme3.audio.openal.ALAudioRenderer.checkDead(ALAudioRenderer.java:230)
    at com.jme3.audio.openal.ALAudioRenderer.playSourceInstance(ALAudioRenderer.java:1009)
    at com.jme3.audio.AudioNode.playInstance(AudioNode.java:210)
```

It throws this repeatedly and eventually locks up JME.

More info....

``` java
Running on jMonkeyEngine 3.1-alpha1
 * Branch: master
 * Git Hash: c5c893f
 * Build Date: 2015-08-17
LWJGL 2.9.3 context running on thread jME3 Main

OpenGL Renderer Information

 * Renderer: GeForce GT 610/PCIe/SSE2
 * OpenGL Version: 4.5.0 NVIDIA 346.82
 * GLSL Version: 4.50 NVIDIA
 * Profile: Compatibility
Audio Device: OpenAL Soft
Audio Vendor: OpenAL Community
Audio Renderer: OpenAL Soft
Audio Version: 1.1 ALSOFT 1.15.1
ALC extensions: ALC_ENUMERATE_ALL_EXT ALC_ENUMERATION_EXT ALC_EXT_CAPTURE ALC_EXT_DEDICATED ALC_EXT_disconnect ALC_EXT_EFX ALC_EXT_thread_local_context ALC_SOFT_loopback
AL extensions: AL_EXT_ALAW AL_EXT_DOUBLE AL_EXT_EXPONENT_DISTANCE AL_EXT_FLOAT32 AL_EXT_IMA4 AL_EXT_LINEAR_DISTANCE AL_EXT_MCFORMATS AL_EXT_MULAW AL_EXT_MULAW_MCFORMATS AL_EXT_OFFSET AL_EXT_source_distance_model AL_LOKI_quadriphonic AL_SOFT_buffer_samples AL_SOFT_buffer_sub_data AL_SOFTX_deferred_updates AL_SOFT_direct_channels AL_SOFT_loop_points AL_SOFT_source_latency
AudioRenderer supports 64 channels
```

Running 64-bit Linux Mint.

data.title: Added LWJGL 3.x module and implementation in regards to issue #314
data.body:
I realise this is a huge pull request but most of the real changes are in the new module so new files altogether.

Some other changes will have been made, in particular to how lwjgl native libraries were registered, this now happens in the two modules jme3-lwjgl and jme3-lwjgl3.

I also took the liberty to change the info log statement of the audio renderer to better match the one of the gl renderer.

Take note that the jme3-lwjgl3 module currently depends on LWJGL 3.0.0b which is a snapshot version. It will probably stay like this until we get a proper 3.0.0 version.

Support for keyboard, mouse and joystick is all working with a new joystick mapping added as well.

Also note that currently there will be some duplicate code between the jme3-lwjgl module and the new jme3-lwjgl3 module.

data.title: Node: fix CollideWith
Substring gets negative value all the time.
data.body:
I want to use substr for getting all the characters in a string to make a text parser.

substr(0,1) works
substr(1,1) works too,

but everything above 1 comes in as negative number plus 1.
e.g. substr(20,1) gives back an error stating that -19 is out of index.

I cannot even use src.substring(src.length()-1,1) --> The first one comes ever in as negative number.

This is with the normal substr function, I don't get it. 
I have Linux Ubuntu and OpenJDK (IcedTea 2.5.6)

I don't know if this is jMonkey-related or OpenJDK related so I post it here.

data.title: Method createChannel() of AnimControl throws NullPointerException in SDK JMonkeyEngine 3.1 Alpha
Sdk TerrainEditor : changed paintTool toolTip
data.body: Changed the paintTool tooltip text to match the tool actions

data.title: Blender loader doesn't use active UVMap if more than one UVMap is present
data.body:
Blender allows to define multiple UVMaps for a geometry/mesh. Only one of them can be active at a time and will be used during rendering.

jME's Blender loader does not load the _active_ UVMap from the .blend file, but seems to always pick the last one in the list, no matter if it is active or not.

Expected behavior:
The loader should only load and use the active UVMap.

Workaround:
Delete all but one of the UVMaps in Blender.

data.title: Fixes Issues #313 & #64 : Calculation Errors for custom Meshes & Deprecation of VB.updateData()
data.body:
Quite a simple commit:
- computeNumElements could return -2 depending on the Mode (TRIANGLE_STIRP) and now it always returns zero as it should.
- The Statistics-Render will now crash when there is an erroneous Mesh (without proper tri/vert count).
  Note: This also means that a clean `Geometry g = new Geometry("Geo", new Mesh());`will lead to a crash as the plain constructor doesn't set the tri/vert count.

Also note that when you use BasicGameTemplate the vert-count goes up by 4 when adding an "empty" Mesh, this is because the object-count goes up from 9 to 10 and thus requiring another digit.

Edit: Sorry, I was unable to open two separate pull requests since Github always wants to use the newest version of my fork :/ What would've been the right way? One branch for each new feature? (Like each issue?)
